ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: As a male student who took this course, I would highly recommend it. The class taught me a lot about the women's position in society, and how that varied over time and place.
Discussion
I loved this class, I learned more about how my own identity has impacted different groups of people, and my essay writing skills were pushed in new ways.
interpreting primary sources

Through the class I developed a skill which requires insightful understanding and questioning of historical pieces both primary and secondary. Primary analysis of paintings and photographs was another critical skill that I developed throughout the class.
Learned about womens history throughout time and key themes across various regions! As well as gained better academic  writing skills
I learned how to analyze documents and think deeply about sources, their context, authors, and issues surrounding their message.
I learned to be more concise and intentional in my writing. I also learned to effectively and efficiently select evidence in readings that are suitable to my arguments.
This was a great introductory history course. I learned valuable skills in historical reading and research as well as historical writing.

This class made me this more deeply about the relationship between women and different societies throughout history. It taught me tk be a better writer and to think more critically on topics that I had previously believed I was knowledgeable in.
More information and background on women's history through time
I developed better skills at discussing topics and writing about them. I had to learn how to express my opinions and thoughts, which I havent done much before.
I developed the ability to understand historical texts and feel comfortable in a discussion based class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed the discussions, but the quality of them was highly dependent on the readings they were based on. While many of the readings were great, some were either not applicable to the discussion, or talked about nothing of substance for pages at a time.
Shorter readings

strengths: fun and important material 
weakness: too much homework each night

Strengths: interesting readings 
Weakness: more guided discussions

Some strengths of this course were the readings chosen which were always very interesting and the class discussion format. I also really enjoyed our class trip days to the Yale Art Gallery, Center for British Art, and the chance to look over some specially selected historical archives from the Beinecke. Some weaknesses were the biweekly reading response discussion posts which were time-consuming, repetitive, and not very engaging to the ultimate class discussion. Another weakness was the professor's lack of general flexibility.

The discussions were very much student led and we came to some really interesting. the course does a good job of discussing well-known topics in a new light and discussing womens issues. I think it wouldve been helpful to get feedback on a draft of our paper first because unless you have time to to office hours there is no way to get specific feedback on your drafts before they are graded.

Professor Tannenbaum does a good job facilitating discussion, and the class is well organized. The selected readings are generally interesting, although some could in the second unit were particularly difficult to get through.

Strengths: The discussions in class are extremely engaging. Everyone is genuinely interested in the course work and seems to have done the readings necessary to contribute to our conversations. The readings we do are also super applicable to the prompts we are assigned for papers.

Weaknesses: Not necessarily a weakness but one should be prepared for a decent amount of reading per week.

Strengths: Professor Tannenbaum curated a list of engaging readings. Assignments never felt pointless, and discussions were well-facilitated.

Weaknesses: None
The biggest strength of this class were the insightful discussions and the interesting field trips the class took.
The seminar style is difficult when discussing complex topics in which we only know a little section. There often is just not enough to say.
I think sometimes the readings were quite long, but because they were interesting it was okay. The discussion part of this class was my favorite.
Strengths were the museum trips and the visit to the Yale Archives. I did not feel as if there were really any weaknesses in this course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. A highly eye opening course that talks about issues of gender expression, women's work, women in social movements, and more. Many of the readings are extremely thought provoking.
Loved the community this class created
Yes.
Yes, I believe this course challenges the student to look at history through an entirely new lens- one that centers women which history often has not.
Would recommended for anyone interested in womens history + want to better academic writing skills
I would not recommend this course to another student. Although the readings are incredibly interesting, the format of the course was, in my opinion, unnecessarily punitive and inflexible.

I would recommend this course. If your are interested in womens history and womens issues, it will be a very interesting class! The readings are engaging. There are three papers: two 5-6 page papers and one final paper that is 10-12 pages on any topic of your choice. If you are looking for a way to get the writing credit, it is not too much writing. If you are not confident in your writing skills, however, there is less hand-holding in creating your essays.
I would recommend this course to any student. Although I am not a history major, it was very enlightening and taught me a lot about writing and analytical thinking.

Definitely! Be prepared for a decent amount of reading and discussion posts per week. If you have the time necessary to invest into this course, I strongly recommend taking it as the content is super interesting and I improved my writing skills.
I would recommend this course to anyone remotely interested in women's history. It was both enlightening and timely.
I would recommend the class. The discussions were extremely interesting and the class felt like a mini-community.
This is complicated because I think the content is interesting and important but the way it is taught makes it much less engaging.
Yes I would, because it explores very interesting topics. I think the student has to be ready to invest time in the readings and the reading responses though.
